The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.

div.head: INSURANCE IN EGYPT.
div.p: The report of the Select Committee of the House of Lords appointed to enquire and report with steps should be taken for the security of British policy-holders in life insurance companies which have their chief office outside the United Kingdom has been published. The report is of considerable interest to Egypt because in view of the terrible scandals in which some of the American companies, doing a large business in this country, had been involved, it has been suggested that the Egyptian Government should take some steps to protect the inhabitants of Egypt from being victimised.

While this Act seems to give general satisfaction, the committee think certain amendments desirable. "The deposit of £20,000 with the Accountant General of the Court of Chancery which the Act of 1870- makes obligatory on any new company, whether foreign or British, has undoubtedly," says the report, "had the effect of preventing the formation of mushroom companies. But under the Act a company is permitted to withdraw this sum as soon as the premiums amount td £40,000. The committee are aware that this sum of £20,000 would be of little use to meet the liabilities of the larger companies which do business in this country. But they feel that if this amount were deposited and could not be withdrawn by any company it would afford an absolute guarantee to policy-holders in foreign companies of being able always to proceed if necessary against such companies in the courts of this country."

The Committee recommend that every company which carries on business in Great Britain should be required to maintain this deposit of £20,000 permanently so long as any policies continue outstanding in the United Kingdom. Some of the foreign and Colonial companies which carry on business in the United Kingdom at the present time have made a voluntary deposit with British trustees of securities to a value considerably greater than £20,000 for the purpose of meeting any claims made on them by their policy holders in the United Kingdom Although the committee cannot recommend that such a deposit of funds should be made compulsory on foreign and Colonial companies, they yet feel that the appointment of British trustees to act for such companies is highly desirable not only in the interests of British policy-holders, but also in the interests of the companies themselves.

They recommend that all insurance companies, whether British or foreign, should be required to furnish the Board of Trade with the full revenue accounts, balance-sheets, and valuation statements of their business, showing at the same time the expenses of management. The committee recommend that the Board of Trade should be empowered to vary from time to time the forms of the questions which insurance companies are called upon to answer and of the returns to be made by them, and also to insist upon such answers and returns being in every respect complete and accurate. The committee recommend that in these returns it should also be made absolutely clear how far the funds of any foreign company are subject to preferential claims in any country in which it transacts business.

The committee consider that it would be very desirable to provide for a statement in the returns made by all insurance companies, both British and foreign, of the market value of the securities held by them. This regulation is in force in other countries.

div.head: New Kuttabs
div.p: New kuttabs have been founded in the markazes of Kos, 8ohag. and lleiha. In each CASE the foundation was due to private initiative.

div.head: Bank of Abyssinia.
div.p: Owing to the death of Mr. Klain, the architect of the Bank of Abyssinia at Adis Abeda, the construction of the building will be slighted retarded.

div.head: Police Recalled.
div.p: A Number of officers of the Police Cairo now on leave in E trope have been recalled before the expiry of their furlough.

div.head: San Stefano Theatre.
div.p: There will be no performance in the above theatre this evening. Tomorrow, Durand et Durand, a vaudeville in three acts, will be given for the first time.

div.head: Wife Murder.
div.p: A native living at Tab*a killed his wife by stabbing her with a knife in the abdomen, and on being arrested declared he had committed the crime owing to his wife's bad conduct.

div.head: "Al Lewa" in English.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel is credited with the intention of publishing a new daily paper in English and French, the object of which is to support "Al Lewa" in its defence of the "rights of the Egyptians."

div.head: The Silly Season.
div.p: A sea-monster, thirty yards long, has been cast upon the shores of Tyre. Its presence has aroused Tyrian curiosity, and although the carcase stinketh, they are bent on securing souvenirs of this leviathan.

div.head: New Portuguese Judge.
div.p: The appointment of a Portuguese judge for Egypt has been definitely decided upon, and a suitable magistrate has been already chosen. He will arrive here in October, and will be appointed to Mansonrah Tribunal.

div.head: Escape from Transport
div.p: While the Turkish troopship Bezmir Alem was passing through the Canal a soldier jumped overboard at Kilometre 34, and although an active pursuit was made after him, he reached the Asiatic shore and made off towards El Arish.

div.head: Fatal Tram Accldents.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon a native girl, eight years old, was run over by a tram at Minet el-Baseal and killed on the spot. This morning a native woman was ran over by a tram in the same quarter, and out to pieces, death being instantaneous.

div.head: Purification of Alexandria.
div.p: The Alexandria City Police are still exerting themselves in endeavouring to purge Alexandria of immorality. Among the excellent measures that have lately been taken is the order issued to the demi-mondaine inhabitants of Averoff and Cleopatra-streets to quit that neighbourhood as Boon as possible.

div.head: Alexandria Tramways.
div.p: Twelve new cars of the latest pattern have last been ordered for the service of the Alexandria Tramway Company They are of Belgian and Spanish make, six coming from the Franco- Beige Company's workshop at La Croyere, and six from a Catalan firm at Barcelona. They are due to arrive here in October and will at once be utilised.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records fivecases one of which ended fatally, and a death in hospital at Alexandria Four of the five patients were Europeans who were found ill in the same house in the Labbane quarter, and one of these succumbed. The other case was that of a native at Minet el Bassal. A fresh case is reported from Suez.

div.head: A Precocious Youth.
div.p: The case of Rossini(19), the Italian swindler, who now awaits trial at the Consular Court at the instance of a large import firm of this city is interesting as a study of criminality at so early an age. Rossini came here six months ago and started a commission business, placing goods on credit against drafts. These, however, he forged, to the detriment of his clients who in lade the Salesian Brothers.

div.head: The Wages of Sin
div.p: A married woman of Mellawi who wished to rid herself of the fruit of her adultery for fear of her husband, consulted an old woman of the fame village. The latter tended her so well that the unfortunate woman died as a result of the complications brought about by the drugs which had been given her. The autopsy on the woman's body revealed the crime and the woman and two of her accomplices have been arrested.

div.head: Bribery In Minleh Prison.
div.p: The Minieh Correspondent of "Al-Mokattam Btatestbat, on going to inspect the moudineh prison a few days ago, the Sab-Moadir of Minieh noticed in the prison yard the servant of Lemlonn Bey Saadi's son, who is wear created there on the charge of inciting the murderers of the Pashn station-master and pointsman, and discovered that the servant had a notebook on him containing sundry entries, including a sum of money paid to the warders as bribes. The warders were immediately suspended and an enquiry was opened

div.head: ARMENIAN BISHOPRIC
POPE AND THE ELECTIONS.
div.p: The Armenian Catholic community of Egypt, which had obtained from the Egyptian Government, by means of a largely signed petition, a regularly approved Constitution, have proceeded to elect three ecclesiastical candidates for the vacant bishopric of Egypt. One of these three candidates will have to be approved by the Armenian Catholic Patriarch at Constantinople, Monsignor Sabbaghian, the late Bishop of Egypt.

The candidates were, in order of votes obtained : Monsignor Davidian, of Cairo, Mon- signor Arpiarian, late Vicar General of the Constantinople Patriarchate, and Monsignor Cayounian, a delegate of the Patriarchate at the Vatican.

It is not improbable that Rome may offer opposition to the final choice of Monsignor Davidian. He is much respected by the Armenian Catholics in Egypt,but he is a strong believer in the autonomy of the constitution of his church in so far as its internal affairs are concerned. The Vatican, however, is always eager to extend its influence among the Oriental Churches and would much like to have "a finger in the pie" in the elections of the Catholic Armenian Bishop.

It will be interesting to see whether Rome will succeed in preventing the election of the favourite candidate for the See of Egypt, although the only grounds for its opposition that he is a firm opponent of Vatican meddling in the internal affairs of the Church.

div.head: THE SULTAN.
div.p: Our Stamboul contemporary the "Sabah" (or "Morning"), speaking, of the manifestations of loyalty and joy occasioned by the news of the recovery of H. I. M. the Sultan, dwells upon the great virtues which distinguish hi9 Imperial Majesty, his constant solicitude for poor, and his inexhaustible generosity, which has won for him the unlimited devotion of his subjects.

The 'Sabah" publishes the text of a letter received at the Imperial Palace from Djisri Mustapha Pasha, a town on the Turko-Bulga-rian border.The writer of the letter speaks of the unalterable loyalty of the troops, and of the indescribable enthusiasm caused in the ranks by the news of his Majesty's recovery.
On receipt of the joyful news officers and men assembled on the public square where an Imam recited prayers for the preservation of the precious health of the Sovereign.
The proceedings dosed with loud cries of Long Live the Padishash."

It is lamentable to find that despite the fervent devotion to the Caliph daily preached by the vernacular Press, the total subscriptions for the Sultan's accession fete only amount as yet to L.E. 135. The parsimony of the Egyptian in this matter is far more eloquent than the leading articles brim fall of loyalty to the Sultan such as appear with such mono tonous regularity in the columns of our Pan- Islamic contemporaries.

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE IBRAHIM.
div.p: Prince Haidar has written a truly remark able memoir on the late Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim to a local contemporary. In the course of this article, which is embellished by long quotation from Laplace's Theory of Probabilities, the Prince gives the following report of a conversation with the deceased:—

div.head: GERMANY AND EGYPT.
div.p: THE POLICY OF BISMARCK-

The belief that occasion will shortly be found, indeed it has not already arisen, for Germany to bring forward certain wishes in connexion with Egypt, continues to be sedulously fostered by the German Press. By this time, of course, the plan of this mid summer campaign has so far developed that England is now represented as being anxious to obtain Germany's consent to Lord Cromer's proposals for the reform of the judicial and adminis trative systems. The manoeuvre is sufficiently familiar.

In the circumstances it may be pertinent to recall the attitude of Bismarck towards Great Britain's position in Egypt On March 2, 1885, in consequences of certain misgivings with regard to German policy which had been expressed by the late Lord Granville, the Chancellor declared in the Reichstag that, while he had consistently declined to make any official suggestion in connexion with the British administration in Egypt, he had intimated to the British Government that if he were English Foreign Minister he would not advise Great Britain to annex.

Egypt at that moment, but to make herself predominant as the Saltan's "lease holder." The effect of this policy would be to prevent France from taking offence and to promote the good understanding between England and Germany. In expressing this opinion to the British Government Prince Bismarck added that if, on the other hand, England should prefer to annex Egypt, Germany "would not consider it incumbent upon her to prevent such action." Friendship with England he maintained to be far more important for Germany than the fa tare of Egypt.

Times have changed, however, and modern German policy is not always true to the Bismarckian traditions of 20 years ago. Nevertheless, the "Vossische Zeitung" declares that Bismarck's word i are as true to-day as ever they were, and that German policy with regard to Egypt could not possibly have changed in the interval. Unfortunately, the Berlin journal ignores the faot that meanwhile the Baghdad Railway scheme has come into existence. In spite of this omission, however, is perfectly accurate in pointing out that "Germany has no interest whatever either in disturbing the friendship between England and France or in obstructing British policy in Egypt, and least of all in masking her support of that policy conditional upon equivalent services in return."

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL.
div.p: In reply to our Paris correspondent's telegraphic summary of the article in the "Temps," which represented Mustapha Pasha Kamel as being "no friend of the Egyptian?, bat as working with Baron von Oppenheim in the interests of Turkey," the "Lewa" and the "Moayad" have, as is only natural, swung out their cudgels of blatant prot3st and puerile literature to disprove the charges preferred against the Egyptian "patriot."

The "Lewa" cites in defence an article which it published on May 9, re the Tabah incident, and in which Mustapha Kamel exhorted Mus3ulmaD8 not to believe in Germany, which, like the other Powers, works only in its own interests. "It was these interests," adds the "Lewa," "which dictated Germany's policy in the Boer War, and in the Egyptian Question, for Germany never supported the Ocupation except to deepen the abyss which the Egyptian Question had dog between France and En-gland. Is this the language," concludes the "Lewa," "of an organ in the fief of Germany 1"

The "Moayad" ridicules the article of the "Temp?," and declares there is nothing in the Egyptian situation to warrant the change of which the great Parikiac organ speaks, especially as Mustapha Kamel has no representative capacity in Egypt.
Rather the "Moayad" inclines more to the belief that the French papers have been influenced by certain English circles who desire to take measures against the editor of the "Lewa" personally.

div.head: GERMAN WELT POLITIK.
div.p: German Welt Politik is at work in every sphere, and the latest scheme of action is characteristic of its methods. The Statthalter of Alsace has been authorized to found at Altkirch a seminary for the Order of the White Fathers, which is to educate Catholic missionaries for the German African colonies. This seminary is to open in October and will start with thirty students and six of the white mocks who have come from Africa. The head of the seminary is Father Frohberger, an alumnas of Altkirch College, and a native of Treves.—This latest move is contrasted with the policy of the French Government, which has expelled the Order from the Algerian Hinterland, where they did good work in the cause of civilization, while the German Government intends to employ them not only in its own African possessions, but also in Morocco.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Cyprian Prince and Indian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 24th inst., and are due $t Alexandria early on Monday morning,
The Ellerman S.S. Avon sailed yesterday . at for Liverpool direct with a general cargo, including 3,700 bales of cotton.

div.head: The French In Egypt
div.p: Defence of British Rule
The following is the text of the letter published in the Paris "Journal" over the signature "Un groupe de Francais establis en Egypte" :-
Moustapha Kamel Pacha dans une conference prononcee recemment a Londres, a somme l'Angleterra de laisser libre cours aux aspirations nationalistes egyptiennes.

Or, jusqu'a present, l'idee de patrie ne a'etait point affirmee en Egypte ou le fellah ne connalt que le coin de terre qu'il cultive, La jennesse revendicatrice de l'autonomie nationale n'y existe pas, ou n'y a cucune influence, ses aptituds sont si peu notoires que jusqu'a ce jour toutes les fonctions administratives y'sont devolues aux etrangers; engin les promoteurs de l'agitation anti-anglaise sont preque tous d'origine turque et regrettent de ne pouvoir exploiter les fellahs comme le faisaient leurs ancetres sous les anciens Khedives.

Aussi les revendications patriotiques de Mustapha Kamel nous laissent-elles sceptiques. Son journal le Lewa est inspire, dit-on, par le baron Von Oppenheim, ami de Guillaume II, et par Abdul Hamid, dont le Khedive est plus que jamais le vassal docile..

Or,c'est ce Sultan, derriere lequel se tient armee, l'intervention teutonne, qui, comptant sur la fidelite religieusa des fellahs, a provoque l'incident de Tabah, alors que sur nos garnisons du Zinder il encourageait des attaques que nous coutaient la vie de plusieurs officiers; hier encore il faisai violer, par le capitaine Abd-el-Kader, l'oasis de Djanet, de l'Hinterland tripolitain, reconnu territoire francais par l'accord franco-anglais.

Devant ces revendications turques qui se propagent sous le pavillon du fanatisme musulman, les inquietudes de l'Angleterre s'expliquent aisement, Et, bien que le journal Misrengage plutot la population egyptienne a la soumission, Lord Cromer, redoutant avec raison des complications anglo-turques suscitees par l'Allemagne, furieuse de son echec au Maroc, vient de reclamer et d'obtenir le renforcement de l'armee d'occupation.

Les nombreux Francais etablis en Egypte dont la securite et les interets pourraient etre mis en grand danger par un soulevement indigene, estiment justifess ces precatuions de l'Angleterre qui, suivant les paroles memes de Mustapha Kamel, "a un interet evident au progres financier egyptien pour gagner la confiance et l'appui des creanciers de la dette et des colonisateurs etrangers...."

Qu'elle y travaille donc ardemment en reconnaissance de la reconciation de la France a ses droits sur la terre des Pharaons et y maintienne, intactes, les capitulations consenties, sauvegarde de nos droits francais.
Un groupe de Francais establis en Egypte.

div.head: SUDAN APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: Mr. W. B. Echlin has been appointed British Vice-Consul at Port Sudan.
Mr. T. von Becker has been appointed Inspector of Coastguards, Sudan Customs Department.
Temporary Kaimakam C. McKey Bey, Assistant Director of Customs, Sudan Government, has been promoted to the rank of Kaimakam.

div.head: VALUE OF PORT SUDAN.
div.p: Discussing the British Sudan and the rail way from Berber to Port Sudan, on the Red Sea, which opens up the colony, the "Revue" says that.Port Sudan will render immense service to the world's traffic, and from its geographical situation is the natural outlet of Uganda and the Bahr-el-Ghazal. It will constitute a formidable rival to the Mediterranean ports.

div.head: SUDAN GOLD,
div.p: The rate for levying royalty on gold in the Sudan has been fixed at P.T. 800 per okia from the 1st inst.

div.head: "TSAR OF KASR EL DOUBARA."
div.p: TIRADE AGAINST LORD CROMER.

The day before yesterday our native contemporary "Al Minbar" indulged in a violent tirade against the Earl of Cromer, whom it dubs "The Tsar of Kasr el Doubara." Our contemporary remarks that Lord Cromer's ability has found a wide field in Egypt, and continues as follows

Milner, Kitchener, Gorst, and others gained their laurels here, and Lord Cromer sends one of his lieutenants here and the other there, while he remains absolute master from Egypt to Aden. Through his wisdom Lord Cromer has succeeded in gaining the confidence of the Press in England; they all sing his praises and no one dared to raise a dissentient voice. Such has been the case in Egypt and it has caused Lord Cremer to become somewhat despotic, so that he cannot bear to have any one thwart his wishes. He has sent away many independent thinkers, as all those who are acquainted with the "Court" of the British Agency know. In snob a way Lord Cromer has disregarded everybody and forgotten his position and the great power of the British nation, which never spares its servants (as for example, Warren Hastings, Parnell, Boiler, Chamberlain, Milner, etc.). When Lord Cromer knew that some Englishmen had realised the absolute power he wields, he tried in his last report to defend himself by stating that he is under the control of the Foreign Secretary, Parliament, and the local Press. He thought that after this defence all would be wall, but the Denishwai affair has opened the eyes of the English to his position in Egypt and prepared them to hear him criticised. This is the meaning of Mr. Stead's remark that Lord Cromer has exceeded his limits in Egypt, where he has remained too long j also that "had this statement been made three months ago, the man who made it would have been considered a traitor, but now I do not think it is so." True, a few months ago no one in the wide British Empire would have said that, but after the Denishwai affair many Englishmen have said more than that. The Tsar of Kasr el Doubara never dreamt of this change.

div.head: GAMBLING AT SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Only a few nights ago the Alexandria City Police raided the Villa Margherita at San Stefano owing to the gambling that is per mitted at that establishment. Last night this hotel was the scene ot another exciting event. An Armenian and an Egyptian had been gambling in company with some other men The Egyptian won heavily from the Armenian, who became desperate at his losses and, drawing his revolver, fired five times at the native. The gambler in his excitement aimed wildly and none of the contents of the five chambers of his revolver managed to hit the Egyptian. The Armenian has been arrested.

div.head: A TRAMWAY CONCESSION.
div.p: We announced yesterday that a concession had been granted for a horse tramway between Akhmin and the Nile. According to this concession, which is for 15 years, the passenger tariff is fixed at 15 milliemes first-class and 5 milliemes second class. Freight for the carriage of merchandise is to be 10 milliemes per ton. The concessionnaire further undertakes to carry the mails free of cost and to hand over his rolling stock to the Government at the expiry of his concession.

div.head: FOUM EL KHALIG CEREMONY.
div.p: The cermenoy to celebrate the rise of the Nile will take place tomorrow, on which occasion the following salutes will be fired: -21 guns in the afternoon(El Asr), 21 guns on the arrival of the vessel Akaba at Foum-El-Khalig, 21 guns at sunset, 21 guns after sunset(El Asha), 19 guns on the arrival and departure of his Excellency the Regent. The Cavalry Band will embark on the vessel Akaba at Boulac Arsenal at 3p.m. the same day to accompany the vessel to Foum El Khalig and there to disembark and proceed to the place of the ceremony, where they will take the customary orders from the Governor of Cairo. The following salutes will be fired from the Akaba: -21 guns on the departure of the vessel from the Arsenal, 21 guns aftr the vessel passes Kasr-el Nil bridge, 21 guns on the arrival of the vessel at Foul El Khalig, 21 guns on the departure of the vessel returning to the Arsenal, 17 guns opposite the Nilometer at Roda,21 guns on the arrival of the vessel at the Arsenal.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Dr. Gumprecht, German Consul at Cairo, leaves for Europe on September 10, on two months' leave.
Mr. Rowlatt, Governor of the National Bunk of Egypt, will take a month's leave from the 15 h proxo.

A marriage has been arranged, and will shortly take place, between Mr.Lewis Biddulph, of the Bank of Egypt, son of General Sir Robert Biddulph, late Governor and Commander in-Chief of Gibraltar, and Miss Forbes, of Cairo.
Yassin Bey Mustapha, Moudir of Keneh, contradicts the rumour of his intention to resign. The Bey has quite recovered from the serious injuries he received in the motor accident
Mustapha Pasha Kamel left Vichy on the 16th inst. for Geneva, whence he will go on to Zurich and San Moritz, and after a visit to Paris and Brussels, will return to Egypt about the 10th October.

The "Depeche Tanisienne" says Mr. Perkins, ex-manager of the Water Company in Tunis, has left there for France and England, and will probably not return to Tanis. It is said he will come on to Egypt where "the directors of his company, in consideration of the good and loyal services he has rendered, have obtained for him a very important fishing ooncd8sion." Mr. Perkins has a son employed with the Pohera Company.

The following extract from a Parisian paper will interest the many friends of Lady Zohrab :—"Le 15 aoout, a l'eglise de La Bouille, pres de Rouen, petite manifestation artistique et musicale. Lady Zohrab a chante avec sa voix si pleine de charme l'Ave Maria de Gounod et l'O Salutaris de 0. Legoanere, qui tenait l'orgue avee son reel talent Tous les chatelains des environs etaient accourus chez leur bon vieux cure, ravi de ce succes pour ses pauvres et de la sympathie qui lui a ete si spontanement prouvee."

div.head: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
div.p: An instance of the great cruelty to which donkeys and males have to submit by the overloading of carts was witnessed in the main street of Cairo yesterday afternoon opposite the Continental Hotel, when a cart, laden with wood to such an extent that the wood could hardly be kept on the cart though bound by strong ropes, passed that spot drawn by a very small donkey. The number of the cart was 9565 and that of the driver 10175. A witness drew the attention of shawish No. 1107 to the terrible weight the animal bad to draw and we were glad to note that the shawish made the driver unload about half of the weight. Such oases of interference are fortunately far too rare.

div.head: MOTORS OF THE DESERT
div.p: Mr. J.F. Wells, Inspector-General of the Department of Mines, has had a tricar made for the work of his inspectorate staff. The engine is a 9 brake h.p. and there is a gearbox giving three speeds forward and a reverse. The car is fitted with a special form of luggae carrier and also a twin rear wheel with steel-studded bands to tyres. The change-speed quadrant and lever is placed in the steering column. The back seat can be easily raised, leaving all the working parts accessible. The water capacity is very large, and a light wooden cover is placed over the radiator to protect it from the sun's rays.

div.head: MYSTERIES OF PARIS.
div.p: The extraordinary number of people who disappear from large cities every year is instanced in a startling manner by a statement made by M. Honnorat, the Chief of the Paris Police Department that deals with these mysteries. M. Honnerat says that the enormous number of 18,000 disappearances of people from Paris have been brought before his department. Of these only about one tenth were discovered.

div.head: UN PARLEMENT EN EGYPTE
div.p: Cette question, qui passionne toute la presse d'Egypte a ses échos dans la presse européeni e Le Journal des Débats s*en est occupé àplusiems reprises. Dans son dernier numéro il publie encore une étude d'un correspondant du Caire, que nous allons tâcher de résumer :

Les étrangers soumis aux lois votées par un parlement local sur la proposition du gouvernement égpptien et sous le contrôle exclusif de la Grande Bretagne, c'est la suppression du régime d'internationalisation sous lequel nous vivons ici depuis trente ans. Ce régime a pour tant doté l'Egypte d'une justice éclairés, impartiale,la plus indépendante q i'on puisse rêver, puisqu'elle juge le pouvoir et que le pouvoir n'a auoune prise sur elle. Elle consiste an point de vae législatif dans l'obligation pour legou vernem6nt égyptien de soumettre à l'assentiment préalable des puissances tontes les lois égyptiennes qu'il veut rendre applicables aux étrangers, et au point de vue judiciaire dans la constitution de tribunaux mixtes cù la prépondérance est assurée à l'élément étranger.
C'est un régime de faveur, sans doute, maid profitable à tout le monde, même aux indigènes.

Pourquoi donc ce système est-il condamné par Lord Cromer ? .Ce n'eit pas pour la situation privilégiée qu'il assure aux européens, puisque S.S. reconnaît elle-même la nécessité de cette situation et que la réforme qu'elle propose n'est que la substitution d'un privilège à un autre.Ce n'est pas non plus pour être en contradiction avec l'aooord du 8 avril 1904,puisque les puissances ont bien délégué à l'Angleterre la tutelle fi auière et aimiuiitrative de Egypte, mais elles out expressément réservé le statu quo en matière judiciaire et législative. Lord Cromer ne peut dono faire valoir que des raisons d'ordre administratif ou pratique contre le système d'internationalisation. Dans son dernier rapport on chercherait vainement un exposé des motifs qui mi'itent en faveur de la suppression de l'internationa-lisation jadiciaire ; il s'attaque uniquement à l'internationalisation législative, oontre laquelle il fiait une réquisitoire violent, mais quelque peu injuste: Pour ohaq ie mod'- fication légidative, dit il, o'est d'abcrd la ré union de-» agents diplomatiques accrédités en Egypte ; ceux-ci dé ègaenc ensuite une sous commission pour enquête, et si dans le sein de oes deux assemblées il s'é'ève la moindre controverse de détail, il faut en référer aux quinze puissances; pour la concession fai e a l'une quelconque de ces puissaces il est necessaire de s'adresser a toutes les autres capitales pour approbation; enfin les formalites sont a ce point interminables, ajoute Lord Cromer, qu'on en vient a renouncer a une refrome utile, non a cause d'une opposition quelconque mais parce qu'il n'existe pas de rouage utilisable quie permette de trancher la question. Donc suppression de l'internationslistion legislative et, par consequence normale, de l'internationalisation judicia

Malheureusement, les raisons que fait valoir Lord Cromer en faveur de la suppression de l'internationalisation militent au coutrarie en favuer de son maintien. Il ne s'agit pas, en effet, de creer une legislation en Egypte. Cette legislation existe depuis trente ans, elle a fais la prosperite de l'Egypte, et il ne peut etre question que de son amelioration. Qui ne voit que cetter amelioration.

Qu'y a til de si urgent qui n'ait ete fait? Les lois de police? Un accord en 1889 a cree une procedure nouvelle, tres simple et tres expeditive qui permet de les proposer, de les discuter et de les promulguer en quelques jours. Or seules les lois de police ont un carac ere d'urgence bien marquee; en matiere civile, commerciale, correctionnelle et criminele la lenteur de la procedure legislative est un trein salutaire contre les innovations inconsiderees at dangeresues.
Que devient dans de telles conditions le requisitore de Lord Cromer

div.head: CORRESPONDANCE
div.p: Noua no nom m en pas responsables des opinions émises par nos correspondants, mais nous désirons, dans un esprit du loyale polémique, permettre—dans certaines limites néccaires—une libre discussion.
GRECS ET ARMENIENS.
Monsieur le Directeur de V "Egyptian Gazette."

L'incident très insignifiant qui s'est passé dimanche dernier entre an Aiménien et on vendeur de journaux grec au Café Mehemet Ali, a été tellement mal interprêté par la presse de notre ville et spécialement de la part des journaux grees qu'il est indispensable d'éclaircir la question pour éviter tout malentendu.

Ii ne s'agit ni de haine ce race, ni de senti ments nationaliste on patriotique, ni de question gréco-bulgare. Voici le fait dans sa banalité ridicule - Un Arménien demande à an vendeur de journaux grecs le nom de l'évêqae dont le portrait était reprodait sur le joarnal qu'il tenait entre les mains. Le vendeur de jonrnaox, au lieu de répondre anssi sériense meut que la question lui était posée, se met à proférer des injures à l'adretse de l'Ar- méuien en question et la conversation se change en une discussion plus ou moins vive, .aquelle prend fin de suite par l'intervention des agents de pohoe.
C'est tout : une simple rixe entre deux ou trois personnes et il est étonnant que des journaux grecs fassent de cela un sujit d'article de fond.
UM ARMENIBH.
Alexandrie, le 32 Août 1906.

div.head:
Balkin Imbroglio
The Troubles of Bulgaria
Quarrel with Russia
END OF PANIC.

div.p: According to the latest accoonts direct from Santiago, about 50 persons have been killed at Valparaiso and the same number at Santiago. It seems that many poblio buildings, including tho>e of the Ministry of the Interior and the Palace of Congress at Santiago, have been damaged. (Reuter)

The estimates of the mortality at Valparaiso continue to vary immensely, but it is believed to bo relatively small in comparison to the enormous damage done. The hotels are standing, and all the oooupants are safe. The inhabitants are huddled on the hills, a the parks, and on the beach. The wateraains are burst, and water and food are lacking. / (ftawfsr)
The panic is over. Airong the dead is the representative of the Havas Agency. The losses are said to exceed a milliard of francs. (//.)
The number of dead in the city is 50. (H.)

div.head:
JAPAN AND MANCHURIA.
A BIG LOAN WANTED

div.p: Baron Takahashi, Vice-Governor of the Bank of Japan, is about to proceed to Eugland and America in order to negotiate a loan of 8O,000.000 yen for the purpose of Manohurian enterprise, and also, if possible, to negotiate for a reduction of interest on old loans. (R.)

div.head:
GREAT BRITAIN AND SERVIA
RELATIONS RENEWED.

div.p: Relations between Great Britain and Servia have been renewed. Mr. Whitehead has presented his credentials to King Peter. Cordial speeches were made. (Rdw/ur)
M. Zaimis is to be appointed Governor of the Island of Crete. (Havas)
The Porte has drawn the attention of the Powers to the serious danger attending the anti-Greek movement in Bulgaria. (Reuter)
The polioe have discovered a plot to assassinate M. Failures during his visit to the city. An Italian Anarchist named Cirillo has teen arrested. (Reuter)

Xsa result of the Montagu court-martial, Captain Thomas Adair and Lieutenant Dathan Lave been severely reprimanded and dismissed their ship. Lieutenant Dathan, besides, loses two years seniority. (Reuter)
The King and Queen of Spain have arrived at Cowes.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.
REFORMS IN PERSIA.
div.p: The influence of the mollahs or Mahomedan clergy is peculiarly strong in Persia. They have preserved an ecclesiastical organization unknown in other Moslem countries, and they wield considerable judicial powers. They are the only body capable of standing between the rulers and the people ; and, with all their faults, they have on more than one occasion interposed their influence against misgovernment when carried to intolerable lengths. Naturally also they have of recent years come to stand as the representatives of the nationalfeeling of Persia against foreign, influences. Between them and the Shah the breach has been steadily growing wider. Some time ago the priests at Kcrbelah actually threatened the Shah with excommunication. Last December the leading Mojtehids of Teheran, to express their protest against the misgovernment of the country, practically went on strike by taking eanotuary in a shrine and thus suspending all their judicial work. They were temporarily quieted by promises, which, *gpf course, were not carried out. Bat last month the trouble broke out again, and in a more acute form. Under the influenc3 of events in Rassia tin populace of Teheran began to olamour for some form of representative insti-tutions. Serious street fights took plaoe iu Teheran, and eventually the whole body of Mojtehids left the city, while their adherents, afraid of the vengeance of the Coart faction, took refage in the grounds of the British Legation—an interesting testimony of the confidonce fe't in Persia in our power and our sympathy with reform. ( "Times.")

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
